figurative_meaning: Giving something valuable to someone who doesn't appreciate it.
example: Giving him that expensive watch is like 猫に小判; he won't value it.

figurative_meaning: Killing two birds with one stone.
example: By studying while commuting, he achieves 一石二鳥.
He prefers 花より団子; he values good food over beautiful decorations.

figurative_meaning: Everyone has their own preferences and opinions.
example: In art, it's 十人十色; everyone has different tastes.

figurative_meaning: To emphasize or warn someone strongly.
example: He had to 釘を刺す to make sure everyone understood the rules.
Even the best can fail sometimes; 猿も木から落ちる.

literal_meaning: Buddhist prayers in a horse's ear.
figurative_meaning: Talking to someone who doesn't listen.
example: Trying to explain it to him is like 馬の耳に念仏; he just doesn't get it.
If you keep trying, remember 石の上にも三年.

idiom: 二兎を追う者は一兎をも得ず
literal_meaning: He who chases two rabbits catches neither.
figurative_meaning: Focusing on too many things leads to failure.
example: If you try to do too much at once, 二兎を追う者は一兎をも得ず.
When he explained it, it was like 目から鱗が落ちる for me.
